Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: A multilocus, multi-species study of community assembly in an isolated fauna
Award.AbstractNarration:
A central goal of evolutionary biology is to understand how and when biodiversity develops in the novel environments that are created by changing geology and climate. For example, the island of Taiwan emerged from the sea approximately five million years ago and, through colonization from various places, now contains thousands of unique plants and animals. This study will apply new analytical techniques to molecular genetic data to reconstruct the colonization histories of 24 bird species that are unique to Taiwan. The project will reveal how and when the bird fauna of an isolated island was assembled over evolutionary time and improve understanding of the historical development of the bird diversity seen today.

This project will advance understanding of the evolution of an isolated biota. It also will form the basis for an informal education program aimed at communicating the science of evolutionary biology to the bird-watching general public. The project also fosters new scientific and educational opportunities between students and researchers in Taiwan, Mainland China, and the USA.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In general, two populations that exchange genes evolve together. When they stop exchanging genes, the two populations begin to go their separate ways. When this happens, we say that the populations are diverging. Diverging populations are important because this is how new species are created. Therefore, to understand how all of Earth's amazing biological diversity came to be, we need to understand how and why two populations diverge.

 

Some geographical features promote divergence by isolating two populations from one another. For example, an animal population on an island is often isolated from the population on the mainland. Likewise, a population on one mountain is often isolated from a population on another mountain. In rare cases, a population is isolated on a mountain that is on an island. Such a situation gives us an opportunity to compare the history of lowland island species with mountain island species to determine what, if any, added effects of isolation are contributed by the presence of the mountains.

 

The island of Taiwan has high mountains, making it an excellent natural laboratory for this research. For my project, I used DNA to compare the evolutionary histories of bird species that are only found in the lowlands of Taiwan with species that are only found on the mountains of Taiwan. Although work is ongoing, I have finished reconstructing the evolutionary history of one lowland species and one mountain species. I found that the Taiwan population of the lowland species has been diverging for 0.1 million years. In contrast, the mountain species has been diverging for 2.5 million years. Although I still need to add more species before making rigorous conclusions, it appears the mountains contribute substantially to divergence among populations. This research is a small step forward in helping us understand how biological diversity is formed.

This research is a small step forward in helping us understand how biological diversity is formed. I am committed to disseminating the results of my research to the public. I have made a public presentation at a Bell Museum of Natural History aimed at an audience of non-scientists. I have also given tours of the Bell Museum of Natural History research collections to participants of the Minnesota Master Naturalists Program. The Minnesota Master Naturalists Program is designed to 'promote awareness, understanding, and stewardship of Minnesota's natural environment by developing a corps of well-informed citizens dedicated to conservation education and service within their communities.' I integrated results of this research project into my tours to demonstrate the value of collections in modern systematic research and as an example of the kind of research that goes on in modern evolutionary biology. I am also developing a presentation designed for amateur bird-watching groups that will use this research to relate the science of systematics to non-scientists. The popularity of amateur bird-watching groups makes them excellent opportunities for relating the science of evolutionary biology to the public.
